page.title: 05LAUGHARNE'S ECOLOGY
page.content: Within this area there is seashore, salt marsh, mudflats, the Rivers Taf, Corran and other streams, sheltered valleys with copses/woods, bracken covered hills, farmland and gardens. Laugharne roads are stone- wall lined with wild wall flowers, valerian, ivy-leaved toadflax, poly-podium australe (rare), ox-eye daisy, herb robert, wall pennywort, stone- crops. Hedges hold campion, bluebells, primroses, wood sorrel, wood anemone, early purple orchids and umbellifers. Ferns, bracken, sycamore, ash, oak and some beech. Salt marsh has sweet alison, sea purslane, sea aster, oystercatchers, curlews, peewits, scoters, shelduck, dunlin, cormorants and herons. Buzzards, bats, badgers, rabbits, grey squirrel and mink. Bass, flatfish, mullet, mackerel and cockle beds, the latter newly returned.
